MOVING POV ON a trail of footsteps in the sand... being followed by ADAM EWING (35), a lawyer from the city of Sa Francisco who appears out of place on the shore of this Pacific island.

While my extensive experience as an editor has led me to a disdain for flashbacks and flash forwards and all such tricksy gimmicks I believe that if you, dear Reader, can extend your patience for just a moment, you will find there is a Method to this tale of Madness. My Dearest Sixsmith. I shot myself through the roof of my mouth at four AM this morning with Vyvyan Ayrs’ Luger. He goes to the bathroom and wraps his head in a towel. He gets into the tub and picks up the Luger pistol. FROBISHER (CONT’D) A true suicide is a paced, disciplined certainty. People pontificate, “suicide is selfishness,” while career churchmen like Pater call ita coward’s act typically because they lack the necessary suffering to sympathize. Couldn’t be further from the truth; suicide takes tremendous courage. He puts the gun in his mouth.

Don’t let them say I killed myself for love. Had my infatuations but we both know in our hearts who is the sole love of my short, bright life. As he cocks back the hammer and prepares to pull the trig we cut to black.

A man and his two sons push an overloaded archaic looking hand cart along a muddy wooded trail. They stop at a ford along a river bed, the sun low in the sky.  6. Helping them, without exerting much effort is Zachry who recognize, though he is a decade younger and does not hav the terrible scar.

For me, all started way back when I still had mos’ my teeth. Me an’ Adam, my bro’by law, an his two sons was trekkin' back from Honokaa Market. (CONT’D) Now, I'd got diresome hole-spew that day ‘cos I'd ate a gammy dog leg in Honokaa, an' I was squattin' in a thicket when sudd'nwise I felt the devil’s eyes on me. Zachry defecates in a leafy brush when he feels as though is not alone. ZACHRY (CONT’D) Who's there? The hairs on his neck stand up.
Oh, a darky spot you're in, friend.
Name y'self! Zachry yanks out his weapon.
I got a blade, I have! The voice hisses at him.

Ain’t no blade can protect you from the True-true... Perched above him, wrapped in dusky shadow is OLD GEORGIE devil dressed in black tatters and a battered stovepipe h his spindly arms and legs unfold from beneath him spider- as he stands.

(scared, whispers) Old Georgie... The devil cackles. ZACHRY (V.O.) (CONT’D) I knowed the moment he looked me dead t’eye, my soul was stoned. Suddenly, Old Georgie LEAPS DOWN at Zachry who screams -- staggers, hiking up his pants and runs away, crashing thr the brush straight into a clearing-- Filled with savage-looking tattooed men astride armored horses: KONA RAIDERS. The blood drains from his face as Zachry freezes for a moment, then turns and bolts. They howl as they rear their horses in chase. The underbrush tears at Zachry as he sprints back to his camp. The taunting shrieks of the Kona and the thundering hooves of horses swirl around him, closing fast. Zachry can feel them almost on top of him when his foot g caught by a root and he suddenly drops, disappearing into thick bed of leaves. The horses scream past him. He lets out a breath, still shaking from the chase but as sounds of the raiders recede, he hears their SHOUTS rise renewed. He realizes he has led the Kona to Adam and his two sons.

Now panickin' wings your foot but it muddies your thinkin' too, so I rabbited back to camp. I jus' followed my instinct without thinkin' thru what'd happen. Zachry scrambles from his hiding place and carefully worm his way to the edge of the camp. The Kona have surrounded Zachry’s brother-in-law and neph hooting at them as they toy with their prey. He watches as Adam swings his axe defensively when the cr of a bullwhip sends him to his knees.  Another crack and the axe is torn from his hands. Zachry lies paralyzed by fear as Old Georgie seems to materialize from the shadows beside him; at first, the malevolent smile is the only thing visible.

Yay, stay here. Saaaaaaafe here. Ain’t no sense in trying to help’em. You’ve said it y’self many times, ain’t ya? “The Weak are Meat, the Strong do Eat.” The True-true, what that is. No un‘scapes the True-true. Horror, like a hand of ice, squeezes Zachry’s heart as th KONA CHIEF grabs a handful of Adam’s hair and wrenches ba his head. His blade flashes as he slits his throat from e to ear. OLD GEORGIE (CONT’D) Shame but Adam’s too old for slavin’. Ain’t fit for nuthin’ but feedin’ worms. His youngest nephew screams and attacks but he his quickl and violently subdued. The older boy tries to protect his brother but is also bludgeoned into submission. The two boys are thrown over a horse as the Kona prepare depart.

Dem boys a’ headed t’slave markets. Ain’t nuthin’ y’can do t’stop it. ‘Sides who’s gonna look after your sister and little Catkin? This thought takes away some of the pain and horror of wh Zachry has just experienced.

Yay, think ‘bout Catkin and Rose. Makes thinkin’ about y’self so much easier... don’t it? The face fades back into the darkness while the smile lingers, dissolving into a patch of leafy crepuscular lig Alone, Zachry looks at Adam’s body and begins to weep.  9.
A contract is being signed.

Wednesday, 9th of September. The contracts are signed. My father-in- law should be happy. Reverend Horrox sits across from Ewing and finishes the l signature. EWING (V.O.) (CONT’D) All my worrying due to the delay caused by my failing health seems fatuous. A bit of good fortune-- Doctor Henry Goose had offered to accompany me back to San Francisco and treat me. How I long for this journey to end, to be home again, to be in Tilda’s arms. Close on a pool of smoking red wax as a seal is pressed i it. Above the seal is the signature of Reverend Giles Hor of the London Missionary Society.
There you are, Mr.Ewing. As binding a covenant there can ever be between men outside the province of Scripture.
Thank you, Reverend Horrox. I know my father-in-law is profoundly excited about this deal.
Your father-in-law is a great man. Future generations depend upon men like him; men capable of speaking the truth. Ewing nods like someone used to living in someone else’s shadow.
Adam Ewing and Goose sup on turtle soup with the Horrox family and a few members of his clergy.  10.

When I first encountered Haskell Moore’s writing, its perspicuity struck me as if delivered through Divine revelation. Goose slurps his soup. HORROX (CONT’D) Doctor Goose, a learned man such as yourself must be familiar with his tractus, “The Ladder of Civilization?”
I confess, Reverend, my education remains a work in progress.

How providential your choice of words Doctor, for Progress is precisely the subject. Specifically the kind of Progress that we see here in Bethlehem Bay everyday. But I’m sure Mr. Ewing would be better at explaining the work of his father-in-law than I. Attention shifts to Ewing, who sets his spoon down with a muted clatter against the taurine.
Well, let’s see. It is, in essence, a syllogistic exploration of God’s Will.
(to Goose) I couldn’t understand a word of it Doctor, but when the Reverend explained it in one of his homilies, well, the whole parish felt the presence of our Lord.
Continue, Mr. Ewing.  11.

Of course, he acknowledges that God's Will remains ultimately unknowable, but he suggests that if the miracles of the Biblical Age, can be interpreted as a manifestation of His Will then perhaps that same Hand is responsible for the miracles of Progress. In this Age he argues, it is Progress that elevates man towards his Creator, not Jacob’s Ladder, but rather “Civilization’s Ladder,” that bears us towards the Godhead. Madame Parishioner hums in corseted pleasure.

This explains the advancement of each race, why you have the Anglo- Saxon at the high-point on the ladder, nearest God and the “irreclaimable races” such as the Aboriginal and the African or even our own Moriori, who remain one rung up from the great ape, so obdurate to Progress and to the Word of God, that no one should be surprised when one of them slips off the ladder altogether.
You mean extinction?
Surely a Doctor knows that God’s Will is often an act of mercy.
Amen. Heads are bowed and “amens” mumbled amidst the flickering candle flames. Goose looks at Ewing who has trouble meeting his gaze.

The young byronic Frobisher lies entwined with his lover RUFUS SIXSMITH; deep shadows cleaved into the tangle of sheets frame their coital, luminous flesh.  12. On Frobisher’s back, just below his shoulder there is a strange comet-shaped birth mark.
Sixsmith - I do hope you will be able to find it in your heart... to forgive me. A terrible pounding on the door, jolts the lovers awake.

Mr. Frobisher! Mr. Robert Frobisher! Sixsmith starts to the door but Frobisher stops him thoug the pounding grows more urgent. HOTEL HEAVY (CONT’D) The management would like a word, sir! Mr. Frobisher, open this door! Sixsmith looks at Frobisher, knowing exactly what is abou happen; his lover’s eyes shine in a way that often requir an apology. HOTEL HEAVY (CONT’D) We know you’re in there, Mr. Frobisher. Please, comply! A letter is being drafted to your father! Mr. Frobisher! As the pounding continues, Frobisher slips on most of his clothes including a beautiful waistcoat. As he puts it on he smiles at Sixsmith who smiles back knowing he is about to lose his favorite vest. They stare at one another as if they were the only two pe in the world until Frobisher kisses him one last time. The kiss ends like a spell breaking, the pounding even lo as Frobisher dashes across the room, grabs his small bag Leaps out the window. There is a metal shriek of a bending drainpipe which caus Sixsmith to rush to the window wrapped only in a sheet. Outside, Frobisher thuds to a lower roof below, then with certain awkward aplomb, slips down over the eave and drop the alley below.  13. He sees Sixsmith watching and he bows as though taking a final curtain, gestures as if he was throwing his heart a Sixsmith, flashes a rakish smile and darts away just as-- The door bursts open.

Hated leaving you like that. Wasn’t the goodbye I had in mind at all. But you more than anyone understand the precariousness of my present predicament. Sixsmith smiles with resignation and reaches for his wall
Frobisher writes his letter as the city is smeared with a impressionist’s brush behind him.
I’m sure you'd remind me I brought it all upon myself, Sixsmith, but shrug off that middle-class chip on your shoulder and try to stick with me a little longer.

This time it’s going to be different, I swear to you. This time I have a plan. In the Belgian backwaters, south of Bruges, there lives a reclusive English composer, named Vyvyan Ayrs. You won't have heard of him because you're a musical oaf, but he's one of the greats.
Frobisher gets off the train and heads for the exit.  14.
He hasn't produced any new work since the early twenties due to illness - but the Times review of last week’s performance of his Secular Magnificat referred to a drawer full of unfinished works.
Sixsmith, reading, sadly senses his love traveling furthe and further away.
You see where this is heading?
A crowd boards the ferry. Frobisher is among them.

My scheme had me traveling to Belgium, persuading Vyvyan Ayrs he needed to employ me as an amanuensis, accepting his offer to tutor me, shooting through the musical firmament, winning fame and fortune commensurate to my gifts, obliging Pater to admit that, yes, the son he disinherited is the Robert Frobisher, greatest British composer of his time.
Frobisher sits on the deck, finishing his letter, the chi channel wind fondling his hair.

I know, Sixsmith, you groan and shake your head, but you smile too, which is why I love you. A pretty SAILOR smiles at Frobisher as he puts his letter away. He smiles back. The sailor heads below deck as Frobisher, feeling his luck begin to change, follows. FROBISHER (V.O.) (CONT’D) P.S. Thanks for the waistcoat. I needed something of yours to keep me company.  15.
Sixsmith sighs, a hint of a smile like the taste of bittersweet, fading as he folds the letter and tucks it i a new leather bag as we hear--
Come on, baaaaby, we are meant to be together!

Close on a bag that could be Sixsmith’s, but worn and age a point beyond resemblance. An old man stands waiting for an elevator. Out of the cor of his eye he looks towards the voices and the sounds of party spilling out of an apartment.

Luisaaaaa, I’m tellin you baby, you can’t leave me. It’s a past life thing or maybe a future life, but I feel it, you and me. A man too old for his leather trousers, bare torso and ze waistcoat, one arm wrapped around Luisa’s waist, the othe holding a joint.

Elevator!

Only in the movies, I guess. She resigns, sitting down across from him.
Still glad the Age of Chivalry isn’t dead? She manages a smile.
I'd still rather be here than back up there.
Not your cup of tea, was he? She snorts.
More like an occupational hazard.
What occupation might that be, if it’s not inappropriate to ask?  18.
Journalist to some, bullshit gossip columnist to others. She reaches her hand out. He shakes She pulls LUISA REY (CONT’D) Luisa Rey. it.

Really? Do you know, I subscribed to Illustrated Planet in ‘67 just to read your father’s dispatches from Vietnam. One of the few journalists who grasped the war from the Asian perspective.
Yeah...
I think I read that he had been a policeman, is that right?
Yeah...
But I recall there was some kind of trial, some malfeasance?
My dad could never play the game, so they kicked him out.
And then he became a journalist?
More like a Crusader.
Remarkable.  19.
Yeah. He realizes just how painful the nerve is that he hit.
He must have been very proud of you, following in his footsteps.

Oh, Luisa Rey is no Lester Rey. No award winning copy from war zones. No exclusive interviews with the leaders of the Black Panther party. She’s done nothing with her life but crank out a bit of simpering gossip for a celebrity rag no one ever admits to reading.
Yes, but is it well written, simpering gossip?
Oh, it is excellently written simpering gossip.
Then don’t bemoan any misspent life quite yet. Forgive me for flaunting my experience but you have no conception what a misspent life constitutes.
An awards night for book publishers held at a posh bar wi rooftop garden overlooking the city. In the background, a jazz sextet plays quietly.

‘Twas the Night of the Lemon Prizes, no bigger waste of time in the entire publishing industry. Cavendish stands alone looking out over the rooftops. Beh him, the party crowd: a cloud of critics, compliers, commentators - and writers.  20.

I recall a moment of introspection, at the balcony’s edge, contemplating a change of vocation, why, why would anyone in their right mind choose to be a publisher? Which was when he found me. Bad news inexorably does.
oy, Timothy. DERMOT HOGGINS sidles up beside Cavendish. DERMOT (CONT’D) It’s all fockin’ bullshit, mate. A fockin’ waste.

Probably true, but we never really know what actual effect we have in the Great Scheme of Things. Remember poor Melville; writes a ripping yarn about a big white whale which is summarily dismissed, laughed at by critics, rejected by readers yet, today, lugged around in the backpacks of every serious student of literature in the Western world.
I don’t give a fock wot ‘appens when I’m dead. I want people to buy my book now.
As your publisher, obviously nothing would make me happier but for whatever reason, “Knuckle Sandwich” failed to connect to an audience.
You want a reason? I’11 show you a fockin’ reason. Right there! He points as though aiming a gun at a smiling MAN, thorou enjoying himself. Cavendish immediately recognizes him.
Ahh, you mean, Mr. Finch?  21.
Felix Fockin’ Finch! The cunt that shat on my book in his poncy fockin’ magazine!
It wasn’t your best review.
It was my only fockin’ review!
It wasn’t that bad. He pulls a wadded piece of paper from his pocket.

No? (reading) “Mr. Hoggins should apologize to the trees felled for his bloated autobio-novel. Four hundred vainglorious pages expire in an ending that is flat and inane beyond belief.” Dermot flings his glass over the railing.
Steady now, Dermot. What’s a critic but one who reads quickly, arrogantly but never wisely.
Fockit. He heads for Finch.
Dermot... Swiping two cocktail trays from passing servers he starts banging them together.
Ladies and Gentleman of the jury! Your attention, please! Finch and his gaggle of admirers turn as Dermot bears dow them.

We have an additional award tonight, fellow book faeries! Ooooh’s and chuckles all around Dermot.  22. DERMOT (CONT’D) An award for “Most Eminent Critic!” Competition was fierce but - (he produces a crumbled piece of paper) the panel was unanimous in choosing, Mr.- oh, beg pardon, SIR Felix Finch 0, B and E! Stirrers crow “Bravo, Felix, bravo.”

What might my prize be, I wonder? A signed copy of an unpulped “Knuckle Sandwich?” Can’t be many of those left. The coterie hoots. Dermot seethes. FINCH (CONT’D) Well come on, I’m breathless with anticipation. Just what does that lead-less pencil you call an imagination have in mind to end this scene? The tension goes out of Dermot’s face and he winks.

Oh, I think you’re gonna love this one. He grabs hold of Finch’s lapels, spins him around and wit surprising nonchalance- Judo throws the critic over the balcony railing. Finch’s shriek ends with a terrible wet THUD on the pavem below. The force of the splatter sets off a car alarm. Dermot dusts his lapels and calls over the edge.

Now, THAT’S “an ending flat and inane beyond belief.” The crowd stands dumbstruck, quiet enough to hear champag bubbling as Dermot saunters back to the bar and orders a beer. MOVING IN on Cavendish who watches him, his horror slowly fading as he begins to sense something gathering momentum like music in his head.  23.

My thoughts? If I am honest, I admit that the obvious emotions like shock and horror, flew as Finch had, here and gone, while deep down I experienced a nascent sense of a silver lining to this most tragic turn.
Newspapers and magazines are covered with pictures of Der and Finch, (headlines like “WRITER:1 CRITIC:0” or “Finch’ Final Fling”).

Overnight, Dermont “Dusty” Hoggins became a cult hero to the Common Man. Television News and Talk Shows all circle around the scan of the month. In a quick montage, we can see more and mor monitors, “Knuckle Sandwich” being discussed on every channel.
I have been asked on numerous occasions, what is feels like to be at the center of a media storm.
Cavendish is besieged by a blockade of reporters as he tr to get to his office door.
Save perhaps the blood and the dying, I imagine it feels not unlike being at the center of a shark attack.
He squeezes himself in and manages to hold back the wave microphone-wielding zombies.

However, since there is very little that can be done to stop it...  24. He locks the door and turns looking a bit discombobulated Across the room, MRS. LATHAM stands wringing her hands. Cavendish reaches into his coat pocket and pulls out a bo of Dom Perignon.
One may as well try to enjoy it. He smiles which causes her to smile and giggle.

The highest selling Cavendish title prior to the Dermont sweepstakes was a cookbook penned by Princess Diana’s former horse-groomer. It sold 5,214 copies. A moment later the champagne pops and bubbly froth gushes while on the television in the background-- A smiling Dermont is led towards the courthouse, through human sea of reporters, cameras bobbing like the remains shipwreck.
An old fashioned printing press chugs along, spitting out title pages that read: “Knuckle Sandwich, A Novel of My L by Dermot “Dusty” Hoggins.”
“Knuckle Sandwich” shifted 300 hundred thousand, yes, THREE HUNDRED thousand copies in less than two months, and yes, I am still talking hardcover.
A window is being filled with a major display for glossy hardcovers of “Knuckle Sandwich.”

The American publishers, glory glory Hallelujah, they loved the Limey-Aristo-Gets-Comeuppance-from- Downtrodden-Gaelic-Son hook, and a transatlantic auction skyrocketed the advance to giddy heights.  25.
Close as Cavendish opens an envelope. Mrs. Latham stands behind him. When they see the six figure number, she shri
I, yes, I, Timothy Cavendish, had exclusive rights to this platinum goose with a bad case of the trots!
A hand plucks the final “Knuckle Sandwich” from the windo
The window is opened and Cavendish leans out, looking dow the garbage in the alley below.

Yet, being a good North Londoner, which is to say, a devout pessimist, it wasn’t until the check arrived from Hollywood for the rights to the feature film that is in production as I write this, that I distinctly recall the exultation of emancipation. From the window he pitches his old, battered chair which shatters on the cobblestones.
Cavendish leans back bouncing gently in his new high-tech Aeron chair. Mrs. Latham spins like a child in her new chair.
They say success can change a person.
Cavendish stands in his underwear, surrounded by the best tailors money can by, flipping through several fabric swatches as he is measured.  26.
I say, the only thing success changes, is your options.
Cavendish wearing his new suit leans back luxuriantly as talks on the phone.

And of course, your phone sheet. People who wouldn’t have taken the time to scrape me off their shoe were calling on the hour. Mrs. Latham signals to him, holding a sign with the name “McCarthy” to which Cavendish shakes his head with thorou enjoyed superciliousness, before returning to his call.
Cavendish exits after a magnificent day, looking as dappe he feels. He locks the office door and strides down the small street, his shiny new walking stick clicking smartl against the cobblestones.

I was for the briefest of moments, Cinderella, living inside my dream come true, but alas and alack, all dreams perish whence the ticking clock of reality sounds its alarm. Behind him, a car with dark tinted windows starts up and glides in pursuit with the grace of a predatory cat.

If you wish. INT. PAPA SONG’S GALLEY - YELLOW UP - YEAR 2144 The cloned servers lay sleeping in pods. Above them a dim ochre glow seeps out from several orbs. A server is woken at hour four- thirty by stimulin in the airflow. They file one by one into the hygiener, then proceed with assembly line precision to a small locker room where chemically cleaned uniforms arrive just as they do.

After a minute in the hygiener and steamer, we put on fresh uniforms before filing into the dinery. INT. PAPA SONG’S - YELLOW UP - MONTAGE - YEAR 2144 As the lights come up throughout the restaurant, the clon gather for their morning ritual prayer at the plinth of t logoman.

At Yellow-Up, we gather around Papa Song's Plinth for Matins. We recite the Six Catechisms, then our beloved Logoman appears and delivers his Sermon. The Logoman appears as a gigantic 3D hologram and deliver his morning sermon that feels like a recording of someone reading from, “Inspirational Quote of the Day.”  28.
